## Interview Transcript 

## What is your name? Where did you go? What are you doing now? 

Liza Aceron 
Public college in Rizal
Substitute Teacher at Rowland Unified School District in the U.S. 
What did your “day in a life” experience look like when you went to college in the Philippines? Commuted to school by taking public transportation 
6 classes a day \n 

## What did you study in the Philippines? What are some subjects you focused on? 

Studied business administration (her focus)
Majored in Management 
Was there any type of academic counseling/advising in the Philippines? If so, what did that look like? If not, how did you navigate your academics?
Public school, so there were limited resources 
Didn’t have license/guidance counselors
Relied on the teachers instead
In the province, there’s not a lot of choices, so the college picks the classes/they are pre-selected \n 

## If students want to study management, then the college already has pre-selected classes 
What are some main similarities/differences between the education in the Philippines (as a student) and the education in the U.S. (as an educator in high school) 

## Differences 
More freedom in the U.S. in choosing classes 
Take less classes; had 6 classes everyday as opposed to 1-3 classes 
In the Philippines, they teach more practical skills in high school 
How to sew, home economics, make crafts with wood 
Involved building with hands 
Teach students how to set up the table for formal events, how to dress up during interviews etc. 
Teach students about different cultures (Chinese, Japanese, Spanish, American, etc.)
Memorization centered
The teacher rotates; 
The teacher goes to a different classroom when students transition from class to class
Classrooms have a main advisor for the entire class → relates to counseling 
Wore uniforms from elementary to college 
## Similarities 
Grading is the same 
Classes taught in Taglish (Tagalog and English) 
In the U.S., ethnic studies came in later
More critical thinking 
The students rotate \n

## What are some aspects of the Philippine education system that seem influenced by the U.S. education system? 
Side note: transcript mentioned U.S. and State of California 

When immigrated to U.S., had to have her transcript evaluated in the states to compare the units 
The grading system and english classes 
(recent development): K-12 system, but during mom’s time there was only elementary and high school 
English is used as the main language of instruction in college 
Accreditation: when the school is recognized for high status with academics 
Need to meet certain standards for education quality  \n 

## Were there opportunities for career development for Filipino students in the Philippines? 

Had to do independent research on career development 
In other schools, there’s healthcare, IT, vocational centers 
Had internships, but found/applied those on her own
Probably had one, didn’t utilize much \n

## Were the classes mainly taught in English, Tagalog, or another Filipino language? What classes were taught in English? In Tagalog? 

Humanities, math, economics, etc. taught mainly in english
Mix of Tagalog and English 
Filipino 101
How to write in Tagalog; reading and writing compositions 
Tagalog is really deep \n 

## What was it like to balance family responsibilities and school? 

Really hard because she was a working student 
Didn’t have time to join other clubs and organizations because had to take care of family
Also had to commute, needed to go home instead of club meetings after school so that she doesn’t miss transportation 
Certain times of taking transportation \n 

## Is there anything else that you would like to add on about your experience? 

Really hard to commute, public transportation had specific times 
School is from 7am-5/6pm 
Differences between evaluated transcript and original transcript 
Clubs: dancing, singing, etc. 
Classes:
Fundamentals of Typing; used typewriters
Social amenities 
Educational computing 
Studied books about Filipino figures, like Jose Rizal
Macro/Microeconomics 
Did a lot of history; Chinese History, American History, Spanish History 
Business Psychology, Stats 
Income Taxation 
Poli Sci classes
